text:
Morris High School meeting its technology goals Students continue learning through technology as bandwidth grows Published: Thursday, Oct. 15, 2015 10:40 p.m. CDT By MIKE MALLORY - mmallory@shawmedia.com 
MORRIS – Morris Community High School may not be able to supply each of its students with an Internet-based device for study purposes, but it’s working to diversify technology usage and infrastructure. Related Links Morris students gather to pray Wednesday morning for national event 
“Technology is ever-changing,” District 101 Board President Denny Best said Thursday during a technology committee meeting. 
The district’s technology plan aims to mirror the goals set forth by the District 101 board plan, Morris Community High School Technology Director JD Morrison said. 
Although District 101 Superintendent Pat Halloran said it’s probably not a good financial decision right now to reach an agreement with a company to provide a one-to-one technology ratio, there are incoming freshmen accustomed to a one-to-one ratio at their schools. 
“We have to meet those needs,” Halloran said. 
To that end, the district is continuing to plant seeds of technology with teachers who are heavy users of it in each department. 
Those seeds grow when techniques are shared throughout each department. 
Use of devices, such as Google Chromebooks, continues to grow. 
Special education classes will continue to use iPads provided by federal grants, and Morrison anticipates math classes will continue to make good use of apps on iPads. 
Teacher Cindy Shannon said she is glad it has always been a smooth transition with nothing forced on the faculty all at once. 
“It allows teachers who are comfortable with technology to put something in place and teach others,” Shannon said. “Some teachers are hesitant, while some are proficient. I like the way it’s been put in.” 
Shannon said the use of learning management systems such as Schoolnet and Schoology during the past three years has allowed the school to track individual student and class success more efficiently. 
Schoolnet provides instant test feedback and historical data, helping departments to identify trends, weaknesses and strengths. 
The first class to use it was driver’s education, and it has grown since. 
“The more teachers use technology, the more they like it,” Shannon said. 
The same could be said for students. 
Morrison said he frequently stops in the library and finds heavy student usage of devices with few problems. 
Halloran said students sometimes are in the library well before classes start using devices to complete their work. 
To support all of the online activity, the school continues to add network connections and has the infrastructure in place to support growth for at least another three years, Morrison said. 
“It’s a continuous process,” he said. “We’ve received great feedback from teachers on our bandwidth even at peak usage times.”
